titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Friday 1. Octr 1847. Dr Woodward advises Huxham’s tincture, and Galvanic shocks—
Edmund Chadwick for contribution to Starkey Seminary Yates County, New-York. I gave him a volume on freemasonry but no contribution for Starkey Seminary.

Ride before dinner with Mrs Charles her Mary and Miss Cutts Dined at my Sons— I walked round the long square at Sunset— My wife with Mrs John, Miss Cutts, and Mary Louisa—and my Son and his daughter Louisa Catherine went to Boston to see the Italian Opera Corrado of Altamura at the Howard Street Theatre— They got home just before midnight— Mrs C. F. came and spent part of the evening with me also Elizabeth C and Isaac Hull Adams

Saturday 2. Octr 1847— A night of mercy and partial repose—distress’d morning— Walk round the long Square— Received a printed circular invitation from Elias G Drake. Hamilton Fish, William Hall, Joseph C. Hart, and Calvin Pollard, Committee of arrangements, of the Washington Monument association of the City of New-York to attend at the laying of the corner stone of the monument on the 14th. of the present month of October, anniversary of the surrender of Cornwallis 19 Octr 1781. with a request for an early answer Letter from John S. H. Fogg South Berwick Maine 30 Septr asking for an autograph of my father or any other PUS. Ride at 4 30 P.M to Braintree Railway depot— My Son and his wife here.

Sunday 3 Octr 1847. An uneasy, comfortless night— Mr Lunt administered the communion and preached from Luke 13.23.24. In the afternoon Mr Simmons preached from Matthew 11–11 the character of John the Baptist— I walked to and from meeting A.M but rode home P.M. Visit from Mr Loring of Hingham and from Josiah Quincy, who proposes to go to Cambridge to see the Observatory— My Son and his wife here

1847. Monday 4. Octr— Cheerless and uneasy Night. My wife with Mrs John Adams Mary Louisa and Miss Cutts went into Boston this morning— I walked round the long square, and on my return found Miss Elizabeth Susan Quincy and Miss Abigail Quincy here— The Ladies all returned from Boston to dine— Rode after dinner with Miss Smith and Miss Cutts— Evening visits from Mr and Mrs Emmons My Son and his wife and daughter were also here.

Tuesday 5. Octr— An indifferent night— From half past 12 at nigh to half past two at P.M. I rode with Mrs C. F Adams and Mr Dehon of New York to the quarries where . . . at might we alighted— I dined with Mr Dehon and a lost my afternoon ride— Afternoon I los my time— Evening slumbering, my son and his wife here

Wednesday 6. October 1847— A night res. . .— Walk around the long square before dinner— Met and walked with Price Greenleaf— Received five printed tracts on Poverty Prosperity and Religion, united— Letter from Henry Gassett enclosing one from Benjamin Ferris Bonair Harford County Maryland 9. mo. 25. 1847. to him— He wants to get a present of a book to me

Thursday 7. Octr 1847. At 8 O’Clock this morning I called in my carriage upon ex president Josiah Quincy at his house and we went together to Cambridge—first to President Edward Everett’s house, and he went in a carriage with us to the observatory where we found the observer William Cranch Bond and his Son George C Bond—but the Perkins professor of mathematics & astronomy was not there— The great Frauenhofer Refractor or equatorial was completely mounted on its stone pier, but not yet provided with a swinging chair for the observer— There is one making for him at present— There is also a large transit instrument to be received from Simmes at London, its object glass having proved defective, requiring the construction of another— The sky was cloudy and we could not get a sight of the Sun—

About noon we returned to President Everett’s house and saw Mrs Everett—after which we returned to Quincy— I left Mr Quincy at his house and reached home to dine soon after 2 O’Clock. I walk’d round the short railway square after dinner
Dr Woodward was here— He modified his prescriptions—but the only prescriptions for me are Patience, Resignation, and submission to the will of my maker.

Mr Nathaniel H. Emmons my neighbour was here— He left with me two volumes of a new edition of Rogers’s Poems which he is about to present to his friend J. H. Meredith of Baltimore and in one of which, he requested me to write a few lines, all to me but a physical impossibility.

I walked to the Stone Bank, to deposit a check for 100 dollars given me by my Son and to draw two checks for 100 dollars each one for household expenses to Mrs John Adams, and the other to repay to my wife 100 dollars which I borrowed of her last Summer— The Bank door was lock’d and a paper pasted on it, that the Cashier was gone to Boston and would be back at 12 Oclock
Saturday 9 Octr. 1847— I wrote a four lines in a . . . to be . . . in one of the volumes of Rogers’s poems, at the request of Mr. Emmons for a present Mr. J. H. Meredith— Prose— I cannot write verse—

I walked to the Stone Bank—deposited the check for 100 dollars given me by my Son and drew two checks for 100 dollars each one in bills which I gave to Mrs. John Adams for household expenses and the other in gold 18 half eagles and 4 quarter eagles which I gave to my wife in repayment of 100 dollars which I borrowed of her last June.— Ride after dinner with Mrs. Charles to Braintree and took from her house Miss Sampson home.

Sunday 10. Octr 1847. Revd John H. Morison of Milton preached by exchange with Mr Lunt. Morning text Hebrews. 12.1. Afternoon text John 4–32. Mr Morison dined with us— I forgot to mention that on Sunday 26 Septr. Mr Lunt gave out to be sung Hymn 138 of his Christian Psalter— I cannot describe and no one can conceive my feelings on that occasion— It has happened twice before only by Mr Lunt and once by Dr Frothingham in Boston. Mr Beale and his daughters were here this evening.

The day comes and goes and it would require more than poet’s invention to select daily incidents in my life worthy of being committed to paper— I still struggle against my fate—and force my hand to write when it has been from the 20th of last November disabled by an almighty hand; forever. I rise from bed, before the Sun, often after a sleepless night, unable but with assistance of my nurse Mrs Ellenor Goods to clothe myself— A walk before dinner round the long railway square, a ride in the carriage with my wife or daughters to Braintree or Milton, with evening visits from my son and his wife, with frequent exceptions, and then half the time sleepless nights compose the tissue of my life—and I still cling to it— I ought to pray fervently for its close. No visitors this day—

A fine day— My wife, my daughter Mrs Charles, and my grand-daughter Mary-Louisa went to Boston, and returned to dine— I walked round the long railway square before dinner, but lost my afternoon ride— Received a Letter from Ezekiel Bacon, Utica, New-York 8. Octr 1847 about the leading Article of the Democratic review of this month of October— My son was here this evening without his wife
Joseph H. Adams here, went to Charlestown—

Recd. pamphlet proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences— Afternoon ride with my wife Mrs Charles and her child Mary— My Son here in the evening— We left Mary-Louisa to pass the night with Elizabeth C. Adams— Desponding eve.
Thursday 14 Octr. 1847. No supper last Night— Slept till daylight— Tantalus banquet— Letter from W. J M’Cormick heretofore Post master of H.R.U.S— Candidate for the approaching congress—

Walk round the long railway square before dinner; and read Dupuis—Treatise on the Eleusinian Mysteries, and all the ancient initiations including those of the Christian religion— Ride round Milton hill with my wife Mrs Charles and Mary— Charles and his wife here.
1847. Friday 15. Octr 1847. half a nights rest—half sleepless— Andrews fishmonger. Rockcod 40 cents— The crown Recd. Protestant Quarterly Review— October 1847.

Taylor meeting Scott County Kentucky— No date— Nomination of Genl Zachary Taylor for P.U.S.— Walk round the long railway square— Mrs Beck from Charlestown—petitioner rejected and mendicant buys land—builds a house on a bridge at Charlestown and fears it will be taken from her for debt— I must call up her petition again in H.R.U.S. She thinks also of applying to Coll Perkins— I gave her a dollar—

Visit from Mrs Josiah Quincy, and Miss Abby Quincy— They remove to Boston for the winter next Monday— Afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and little Mary on the road to Squantum, by the spot where Mr William Appleton is about to build a house

Saturday 16 October 1847— A quiet and comfortable Night a frosty and beautiful morning— My wife with Mary Louisa went to Boston— Morning visits from a Mr Loring—Revd from the state of Maine, and from Revd Mr Harding of the Railway village church Milton.

Meridian walk across the lane round the long railway square Met lying on the side of the lane on this side of my son’s house Joshua Yeamans, with papers a claimant for a pension for services in the last War with Great Britain—he shewed me one of his papers a certificate from his Captain Samuel Hough— I told him he must take his papers to Washington and I would aid him if it should be in my power

Received a Letter from Natl. Frye Washington 12 October 1847— Columbian Mills damaged by a great flood— My wife came home to dinner— Mary-Louisa, at 4 O’Clock after dinner— I rode with Mrs Charles and her Mary to Braintree and we took Miss Samson home— My Son and his wife were here till 9 O’Clock

Sunday 17 October 1847. A quiet Night and beautiful October day— Mr Lunt preached A.M. from Mark 12 42.43, and P.M. Revelation 5.6— Evening visit from President Quincy, and my son was here till the . . . o’clock bell.

lg.l: Millions of spiritual creatures walk the earth
Unseen, both when we wake, and whever we sleep:
All these with ceaseless praise his works behold
Both day and night— How often from the steep
Of echoing hill or thicket have we heard
Celestial voices to the midnight air
Sole or responsive each to others note
Singing their great Creator? oft in bands
While they keep watch, or nightly rounding walk
With heavenly touch of instrumental sounds
In full harmonick number join’d, their songs
Divide the night, and lift our thoughts to Heaven.

div.p: Paradise Lost 4–677.

A tolerably quiet night—but wrote the above lines with great difficulty— Mary Louisa went with Mrs Miller and Mr George T. Bigelow to Charlestown to visit Lieutt Joseph H Adams in charge of the Ship Independence—

Received from Aaron H. Palmer 6 copies of a Prospectus of the unknown countries of the East—I.e the principal countries of Eastern Africa and Asia— Walk before dinner round the long railway square— Afternoon ride round Milton hill Louisa Catherine of the hill dined with us. Six partridges. Received Letter from Joseph Henry, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution—with a printed folio sheet anonymous beginning with a note
This article is printed for a special purpose, but is not intended in its present state for the public
Smithsonian Institution—
General considerations which should serve as a guide in adopting a plan of organization—
Mr Henry called upon me and conversed with me last Summer at Washington— It appears however that the Institution is still to be organized
Morning walk round the long Railway square and visited the eastern cellar— Afternoon ride— Mary Louisa came home in the evening.
Anniversary of the surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown
Monument of Washington at New-York
Exhibition at Cambridge— Mary Louisa went with Mrs Miller, and Mr and Mrs G. T. Bigelow, and came home late this evening My wife dined and took tea at my sons up the hill.
examined the central and western cellars
Steamer Cambria arrived at Boston at half 7. this morning
Alexander H Everett died at Canton, China 29 June

Awoke long before daylight— I walked up the hill and spoke with my son before he went to Boston— I wrote to R. G. Metcalf Wrentham—Representative of that town in the State Legislature— Walk round the long railway square—

Elizabeth C. Adams Isaac Hull Adams and Lieutt. Joseph Harrod Adams dined with us— Mr Ewer a member of the Massachusetts historical and Genealogical Society was here after dinner— I gave him an engrav’d print by Ganbrede of Stuarts last portrait of my father, and a print of a profile portrait of General Washington given me by Christopher Hughes— Ride round Milton hill returning by Neponset bridge turnpike with my wife Mrs. John Adams and Elizabeth C. Adams— While we were out Mr Joseph Russell of Boston paid us a visit—we did not see him— My son and his wife spent the Evening here—and Elizabeth C. Adams, who goes to-morrow for New Orleans with her uncle Charles Harrod

Thursday 21 October 1847— An almost sleepless and exceedingly cheerless night— Mary Louisa went to the railway depot and saw the departure of Elizabeth C Adams for New-Orleans— Dr. William B. Duggan and Captain Charles Swift were here— Captain Swift is candidate for the appointment of light house keeper of a new light house to be erected on Minots ledge of Cohasset Rock— Afternoon ride with my wife and Mrs Charles round Milton Hill return by the Neponset bridge Turnpike— I began a Letter to President Edward Everett to send with the Report of the Committee of the board of Overseers on the . . . observatory.

I exhibited to my son, the Letters and receipts from Mrs Catherine Maria Frances Smith, for two payments of 135 dollars each in advance made by him under my direction April and May last, and charged by him to my account, and now credited to the same, from the annuity left by Mrs Smiths brother Thomas Baker Johnson, of which my son is the trustee— Dr Woodward was here this forenoon and made the first trial of a galvanic battery upon my right hand, and as far as I could perceive with no favourable effect— I took my walk before dinner—and my ride to Milton after dinner as usual

Rain great part of the Night— Michaelmy Son’s man shaves me twice a week—Wednesday and Saturday— Ruth Turner has been several days here working for the Ladies— My wife with Mrs John Adams went this afternoon to Boston, shoping and returned after dark— I lost my afternoon ride— Isaac Hull Adams came to stay with us till if it please God we may depart for Washington— I received from Revd Matthew Hale Smith, now Minister of the Church of the Pilgrims, worshiping at the Tremont Temple Boston, a miniature edition and handsomely bound copy of his four discourses addressed to young persons and delivered by him in the second presbyterian church at Washington in April 1846—

A young man from the divinity school at Cambridge named Capen, preached for Mr Lunt this morning from Act 1.8 on the gift of tongues conferred upon the Apostles, on the day of pentecost by the holy ghost—and this afternoon from James 4.14. Joseph Harrod Adams came from Charlestown, and dined with us but returned this afternoon to his ship, the Franklin— My son spent the Evening here— His daughter Louisa Catherine has been much indisposed the last ten days, and is yet confined at home— Our Mary Louisa is afflicted with a whitlow— I walked to and from meeting morning and afternoon—but the decay of my power to walk continues— I think without abatement.

1847. Monday 25 October— A hapless, half sleepless night succeeded by a cloudy day of variable weather sunshine and shower alternate Warm, and blowing the Sirocco Southwest wind— I walked up the hill round the short railway square, barely able to stand on my feet— Called down to an old man named William Hunt, a Mendicant.

I received a Letter from William Clarkson Johnson, son of my deceased brother Charles’s daughter, the first wife of Alexander C. Johnson of Utica, New-York, informing me that he intends to be married during the first of next month to miss Harriet Douw of Albany, and immediately after to embark for Europe to spend the winter, and to return, and resume his business for next Spring—
